File.Title: Organization of Medullary Adrenergic and Noradrenergic Projections to the Periaqueductal Gray Matter in the Rat
File.Authors: HORST HERBERT AND CLIFFORD B. SAPER

Abstract.S: The periaqueductal or midbrain central gray matter (CG) in the rat contains a dense network of adrenergic and noradrenergic fibers.

We examined the origin of this innervation by using retrograde and anterograde axonal tracers combined with immunohistochemistry for the catecholamine biosynthetic enzymes tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), dopamine p-hydroxylase (DBH), and phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PNMT).

Following injections of the fluorescent tracers Fast Blue or Fluorogold into the CG, double-labeled neurons in the medulla were identified mainly in the noradrenergic A1 group in the caudal ventrolateral medulla (VLM) and A2 group in the medial part of the nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS); and in the adrenergic Cl group in the rostral ventrolateral medulla and C3 group in the rostral dorsomedial medulla.
Injections of Phaseolus vulgaris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) into these cell groups resulted in a distinct pattern of axonal labeling in various subdivisions of the CG.
Anterogradely labeled fibers originating in the medial NTS were predominantly found in the lateral portion of the dorsal raphe nucleus and in the adjacent part of the lateroventral CG (CGlv).

Following PHA-L injections into the C3 region the anterogradely labeled fibers were diffusely distributed in the CGlv and the dorsal raphe nucleus at caudal levels, but rostrally tended to be located laterally in the CGlv.

In contrast, ascending fibers from the caudal and rostral VLM terminated in the rostral dorsal part of the CGlv and in the dorsal nucleus of the CG, whereas ventral parts of the CG, including the dorsal raphe nucleus, contained few afferent fibers.

Double-label studies with antisera against DBH and PNMT confirmed that noradrenergic neurons in the A1 and A2 groups and adrenergic neurons in the Cf and C3 groups contributed to these innervation patterns in the CGlv.
Noradrenergic and adrenergic projections from the medulla to the CG may play an important role in a variety of autonomic, sensory and behavioral processes.

Introduction.S: The periaqueductal or central gray matter of the midbrain (CG) consists of the cellular region surrounding the cerebral aqueduct (of Sylvius).
The CG also contains major ascending and descending fiber systems that link the hypothalamus with the brainstem.

Recent studies have indicated that the CG plays an important role in the modulation of nociceptive sensory transmission (Abols and Basbaum, '81; Fardin et al., '84a,b; Nichols et al., '89; Morgan et al., '89; Hamba et al., 'go), regulation of the cardiovascular system (Skultety, '63; Depaulis et al., '88; Carrive et al., '88, '89), and in a variety of behaviors including feeding (Skultety and Gray, '62; Weiss and Liebowitz, '851, defensive behavior (Bandler et al., '85a,b; Carrive et al., '891, and sexual response (Sakuma and Pfaff '79, '80).

Previous studies of CG connections have emphasized its relationships with the cortex, thalamus, and hypothalamus in the forebrain (Morrell et al., '81; Beitz, '82; Eberhart et al., '85; Carstens et al., '90) and its descending connections with the nucleus raphe magnus, ventrolateral medulla and spinal cord (Abols and Basbaum, '81; Beitz et al., '83; Morrell and Pfaff, '83; Carrive et al., '89).

In the course of our own investigations of the projections from autonomic cell groups in the medulla to the parabrachial nucleus (Herbert et al., '901, we observed prominent innervation of the CG as well.
Many of these afferents originated from cell groups containing adrenergic or noradrenergic neurons.
We have therefore systematically examined the catecholaminergic afferents to the CG from the medulla, by using combined tracer methods and immunocytochemistry for catecholamine synthetic enzymes.
A preliminary report of this work has appeared (Herbert and Saper, '88).

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Retrograde double-labeling experiments

A total of 11 Sprague-Dawley rats of both sexes, ranging in weight from 250-400 g were anesthetized with 7% chloral hydrate (350 mg/kg) and stereotaxic injections of fluorescent tracers were made into the lateral portion of the CG.
The animals received unilateral injections of either 50-100 nl of Fast Blue (Illing, GmbH) in dH,O (n = 5) or 30-50 nl of 4% Fluorogold (Fluorochrom, Inc.) in saline (n = 6).
After 5-11 days of survival, the rats were deeply anesthetized and perfused through the aorta with 0.9% saline, followed by 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (PB) at pH 7.4.
The brains were removed from the skull and post-fixed in the perfusate overnight at 4°C.
The brainstems were cut on a freezing microtome at 40 (*m and sections were divided into four series.

These were then processed by the indirect immunofluorescence method with antibodies against the catecholamine biosynthetic enzymes tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), dopamine p-hydroxylase (DBH), or phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PNMT).
Zmmunohistochemistry.

The sections were rinsed for several minutes in PB containing 0.9% NaCl (PBS) and then preincubated in PBS containing 3% goat serum and 0.25% Triton X-100, which served as a diluent for all further incubations.
After 1 hour, the sections were transferred into polyclonal whole antisera raised in rabbits (Eugene Tech), diluted 1:750 (anti-TH), or 1:400 (antiDBH, anti-PNMT).

After incubation in the primary antisera for 24-48 hours at 4"C, the sections were washed several times in PBS, transferred to a biotinylated goat anti-rabbit IgG (BRL) diluted 1:200, and incubated for 50 minutes at room temperature.
After three additional rinses in PBS, the sections were incubated for 50 minutes at room temperature in streptavidin-Texas red conjugate (BRL), diluted 1500.
Sections were washed again in PBS, mounted onto gelatin-coated slides, air dried, cleared in xylene, and coverslipped with DPX.
In preliminary studies, omitting either the primary or secondary antisera abolished staining.

Colchicine treatment did not increase the numbers of TH-immunoreactive neurons in the medulla, and PNMTimmunoreactive staining corresponded nearly perfectly with TH staining in the medulla (Tucker et al., 1987); hence, no colchicine treatment was used in this series of experiments.
Data analysis.
Sections were viewed under a Leitz Orthoplan microscope with Ploem fluorescence illumination, under a N2 filter system for Texas red and an A filter system for Fast Blue and Fluorogold.
Retrogradely labeled, immunofluorescent, and double-labeled neurons in the medulla were plotted with the aid of a microscope stage position plotter system (Minnesota Datametrics).
The coverslips were then removed, and the sections were counterstained with thionin to identify brainstem cytoarchitecture.

Cell counts of catecholaminergic neurons and doublelabeled neurons in the Al, A2, and (21-3 cell groups were performed on TH-stained sections from two brains (total of 22 sections) and PNMT-stained sections from one brain (total of 9 sections).
Anterograde double-labeling experiments
Fourteen female Sprague-Dawley rats weighing 300-350 g received iontophoretic injections of 2.5% Phasedus vulgaris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L; Vector) into medullary catecholaminergic cell groups.

A stereotaxic surgical method similar to the retrograde experiments was used for the injections into the medullary reticular formation, but the injections into the nucleus of the solitary tract were made through the foramen magnum, with the aid of brain surface landmarks for stereotaxic orientation.

PHA-L was dissolved in 10 mM phosphate buffer, pH 8, and was injected from glass micropipettes with 25-40 pm tip diameter by means of a pulsed positive current of 5 pA with a 50% duty cycle, applied for 15-20 minutes.
After 8-12 days of survival the animals were reanesthetized and perfused through the aorta with 0.9% saline followed by a two step pH-change procedure (Berod et al., '81).
First, rats were perfused with 180 ml of ice-cold 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M sodium acetate buffer, pH 6.5, followed by 300 ml of ice cold 4% paraformaldehydein 0.1 M borate buffer, pH 11.
The brains were removed and postfixed overnight at 4°C in the borate buffered fixative containing 5% sucrose.
Tissue blocks were then cut and soaked for 2 days in 30% sucrose in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4 at 4°C.

Sections were cut at 40 km on a freezing microtome, and alternate series were then processed by a double immunofluorescence method (see below) to identify PHA-L labeled fibers that were also immunoreactive either for DBH or PNMT.

Additional series of sections through the CG from each case were also processed by an immunoperoxidase method (see below) to visualize either PHA-L labeled fibers or the DBH-immunoreactive (-ir) or PNMT-ir fiber plexus.
Double immunofluorescence staining.

Sections were rinsed for several minutes in 50 mM Tris-buffered 0.9% saline, pH 7.6 (TBS) and preincubated in a diluent consisting of 3% horse serum and 0.25% Triton X-100 in PBS 1 hour at room temperature.

Sections were transferred into diluent containing the primary goat anti-PHA-L (Vector) diluted 1: 1,000 and rabbit anti-DBH (Eugene Tech) diluted 1:800 or rabbit anti-PNMT (Incstar) diluted 1:5,000, and incubated at 4°C for 2-3 days.

After being washed several times in PBS, sections were incubated in fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC-) labeled donkey anti-goat IgG (Jackson) diluted 1:30 for 1 hour at room temperature, followed by three rinses in PBS and then incubation in biotinylated donkey anti-rabbit IgG (Jackson) diluted 1:800 for 45 minutes at room temperature.

Sections were washed again three times and transferred to streptavidin-Texas red conjugate (Jackson) diluted 1:1,000 for 45 minutes at room temperature, then washed in PBS, mounted on gelatincoated glass slides, air dried, cleared in xylene, and coverslipped with DPX containing 5% v/v @-mercaptoethanol (Merck) to retard fading (Franklin and Filion, '85).
Immunohistochemical controls.

To control for potential cross-reactivity of the secondary antisera, sections incubated in either primary antiserum (rabbit anti-DBH or goat anti-PHA-L) alone were stained with both secondary antisera as in the double immunofluorescence protocol.
No immunocytochemical staining with the FITC-labeled donkey anti-goat antiserum was seen when the goat antiPHA-L was omitted; and no staining with Texas red was seen when the anti-DBH was omitted.
Further evidence of lack of cross-reactivity is provided by the presence of numerous axons that stained with one but not the other double immunofluorescence material (see marker in the Results).
Data analysis.
We viewed the sections with a ReichertJung Polyvar microscope fitted with a B1 filter system for FITC and a G1 system for the Texas Red.
Areas containing double-labeled fibers were subsequently photographed with the two filter systems.
Enlargements of these photomicrographs were photocopied onto acetate sheets and then superimposed to identify double-labeled fibers and varicosities.
Double-labeling was further validated by comparing the shape, size and orientation of the structures on the original photomicrographs and by measuring distances with the aid of a caliper.
Immunoperoxidase staining
Additional series of sections were stained to visualize the anterogradely labeled fibers and the DBHor PNMTcontaining fiber plexus by the peroxidase-antiperoxidase (PAP) method.
Sections were first rinsed in several changes of TBS and then incubated in a blocking solution containing 10% normal swine serum, 2% bovine serum albumin, and 0.3% Triton X-100 in TBS.

After 1 hour the sections were directly transferred into the primary antiserum, either rabbit anti-PHA-L (Dako) diluted 1:3,000, rabbit anti-DBH (Eugene Tech) diluted 15300, or rabbit anti-PNMT (Incstar) diluted 1:5,000 in a diluent containing 1% normal swine serum, 1% bovine serum albumen, and 0.3% Triton X-100 in TBS, and incubated for 2-3 days at 4°C.
Sections were then rinsed for 30 min in several changes of TBS, and incubated for 1.5 h at room temperature in unlabeled swine anti-rabbit IgG diluted 1:50 in the same diluent.
Sections were extensively washed in TBS and then incubated in rabbit PAP-complex (Dako) at 1:ZOO dilution.

After 1.5 h at room temperature, sections were rinsed again in several changes of TBS and then incubated for 8-10 minutes in 0.05% 3,3-diaminobenzidine (DAB, Sigma) containing 0.0 1% hydrogen peroxide (H,O,).
Sections were mounted onto gelatin-coated glass microscope slides, air dried, dehydrated in graded ethanols, cleared in xylene, and coverslipped with Entellan mounting medium.
Adjacent series were stained with thionin to identify cytoarchitectonic landmarks.
Data analysis.
Sections were viewed under both brightfield and darkfield illumination.
The subnuclear distribution of PHA-L labeled fibers in the CG was mapped with a camera lucida drawing apparatus.

Cytoarchitectural boundaries were defined by superimposing projections of the adjacent thionin-stained sections onto the drawings, with the aid of brain outlines and blood vessels as reference points.
Cytoand chemoarchitecture of the CG
To demonstrate the subnuclear organization of the CG, rats were perfused with 4% paraformaldehyde and the brains removed and cut in the transverse plane at 40 km on a freezing microtome.
The sections were stained histochemically for NADPH-diaphorase (Scherer-Singler et al., '83) or for Nissl-substance with thionin.

Results.S: RESULTS
Subdivisions of the CG

Previous studies have proposed a subdivision of the rat CG based upon the cytoarchitecture in Nissland Golgistained material (Beitz, '85; Beitz and Shepard, '85; Paxinos and Watson, '86) and upon cytochrome oxidase histochemistry (Conti et al., '88).
In the sections processed histochemically for NADPH-diaphorase, we have made additional observations that bear upon the delineation of the CG subdivisions.
The terminology for the CG subdivisions is adapted from that of Paxinos and Watson ('86).
in nadph - diaphorase - stained material the cgld stands out clearly because of the dense staining of its neuropil ( indicated by arrowheads in fig . la , d ) .

in the thioninstained sections the laterodorsal subdivision of the cg ( cgld ) can be appreciated by its granular appearance ( e . g . , fig . 1b ' ) compared with the dorsal subdivision ( cgd ) which consists of larger , more darkly stained neurons ( fig . 1a ' c ' ) .
All three subdivisions show a gradient of cell density which increases from medial to lateral (Fig. 1A'-C').
The cell poor band of tissue surrounding the aqueduct corresponds to the medial subdivision (CGm;indicated by the dashed lines in Fig. 1A'-D').
in the rostral aspect of the cg , the lateroventral subdivision is bordered ventrally by the supraoculomotor nucleus ( fig . 1a ' ) .

at the midlevel , the ventromedial part of the cg is occupied by the dorsal raphe nucleus , which is characterized by numerous nadph - diaphorase - positive neurons exhibiting intensely staining dendritic arbors ( fig . 1c ) .
fewer nadph - diaphorase - stained cells are seen in the lateral portion of the dorsal raphe nucleus .
in thioninstained sections , though , the midline portion of the dorsal raphe nucleus as well as its lateral portion are clearly visible ( fig . 1c ' ) .
caudally , the cg contains ventrally the dorsal and laterodorsal tegmental nuclei , both of which are clearly demonstrated in the two stains ( fig . ld , ld ' ) .
the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus is intensely nadph - diaphorasestained , whereas the medially located dorsal tegmental nucleus is less intensely stained .

in the thionin - stained material the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus is seen as a cluster of large , darkly stained neurons that are bordered medially by the pericentral portion of the dorsal tegmental nucleus , a circular group of densely packed , medium size cells .
the midline region of the caudal cg is made up of nadph - diaphorase - positive somata that belong to the dorsal raphe nucleus ( fig . 1d ) .
distribution of catecholaminergic fibers in the cg

sections through the midbrain stained immunohistochemically for catecholamine synthetic enzymes reveal a dense plexus of dbhand pnmt - immunoreactive ( - ir ) fibers and puncta in the cg ( see also : ungerstedt , ' 71 lindvall and bjorklund , ' 74 swanson and hartman , ' 75 hokfelt et al . , ' 84a moore and card , ' 84 chandler et al . , ' 88 ) .
the dbhand pnmt - positive structures are not evenly distributed , but restricted to certain parts of specific cg subdivisions ( fig . 2 ) .
Prominent DBHir and PNMTir staining is present in the CGlv.

at the level of transition from the superior to the inferior colliculus ( fig . 2 0 , a dense plexus of catecholaminergic fibers and varicosities is seen in the ventral part of the cglv , overlapping the lateral portion of the dorsal raphe nucleus ( cf .
Fig. 1C').
laterally , the staining in the cglv is rather sparse , and the more dorsal subdivisions of the cg are nearly devoid of stained axons .
overall , dbhir axons are more abundant than pnmtir fibers , suggesting that both adrenergic and noradrenergic cells contribute to this pattern .
Combined retrograde tracing and immunohistochemistry
unilateral injections of the fluorescent tracers fast blue or fluorogold were placed into the region of the catecholaminergic fiber plexus in the cglv at the intercollicular level ( figs . 3 , 4 ) .

in cases in which the injection was clearly confined to the cg , retrogradely labeled neurons in the medulla were predominantly found in the nuclei of the reticular formation , including the dorsal and ventral medullary reticular fields caudally and the parvocellular and gigantocellular reticular nuclei rostrally .
additional labeled cells were seen in the medullary raphe nuclei , the trigeminal promontorium , the dorsal column nuclei and the vtastibular nuclei .

this distribution of retrogradely labeled neurons is in general agreement with earlier studies in the rat ( e . g . , beitz , ' 82 marchand and hagino , ' 83 morrell and pfaff , ' 83 beitz et al . , ' 86 hamba et al . , ' 90 ) , the cat ( bandler and tork , ' 871 , and the rabbit ( meller and dennis , ' 861 , and will not be described in detail .

we concentrate here on the numerous retrogradely labeled neurons that were intermingled with the al / a2 noradrenergic and the cl - c3 adrenergic groups in the nucleus of the solitary tract ( nts ) , the caudal and rostral ventrolateral medulla ( vlm ) , and the dorsomedial medulla ( dmm ) in the region of the nucleus prepositus and medial longitudinal fasciculus ( figs . 3 , 4 ) .
subsequent immunohistochemical staining for the catecholamine synthetic enzymes th , dbh , or pnmt revealed that numerous neurons in these regions contained both labels .
nucleus of the solitary tract .
in the nts retrogradely labeled neurons were distributed throughout the a2 cell group in the caudal commissural and medial subnuclei ( figs . 3 , 4 ) .
the total number of retrogradely labeled neurons was about twice as high on the ipsilateral compared to the contralateral side .
only scattered retrograde labeling was found in the ventrolateral and rostral nts subnuclei .
overall , of the thir neurons in the nts , 22% were double - labeled ipsilaterally ( e . g . , fig . 5a , a ' ) and 9% contralaterally .
among pnmtir neurons , 15% of those in the dorsomedial nts were retrogradely labeled on the ipsilateral side and 8% contralaterally .
very few thir neurons in the area postrema or in the classical c2 group , along the rostromedial border of the nts , were retrogradely labeled , however .
ventrolateral medulla .
retrogradely labeled neurons were intermingled with the allcl cell group at every level of the vlm .
although similar numbers of retrogradely labeled neurons were identified on the two sides of the brain ( figs . 3 , 41 , double labeled neurons were predominantly found ipsilaterally .
For example, 36% of THir and 42% of PNMTir neurons were double-labeled ipsilaterally, whereas only 18% and 13%, respectively, were double-labeled contralaterally.
rostra1 to the area postrema , the numbers of thir and pnmtir neurons per section in the vlm was similar , indicating mainly an adrenergic projection .
caudal to the area postrema , few pnmtir neurons were seen , so that the double - labeled cells were mainly noradrenergic .
we conclude that the a1 noradrenergic and c1 adrenergic cell groups each provides a major source of catecholamiriergic innervation of the cg( fig . 5b , b ' , c , c ' ) .
dorsomedial medulla .
the region of the c3 adrenergic cell group , surrounding the nucleus prepositus and medial longitudinal fasciculus , also contained substantial numbers of double - labeled cells ( fig . 5d , d ' ) .
as in the vlm , equal numbers of retrogradely labeled cells were found bilaterally ( figs . 3 , 4 ) , but double - labeled cells were primarily found on the ipsilateral side .
a total of 23% of pnmtir cells in the c3 group ( bilaterally ) were also retrogradely labeled .
Anterograde tracer experiments

to determine the distribution of catecholaminergic afferents from the medulla within the cg , injections of the anterograde tracer pha - l were placed into the cell groups containing double - labeled neurons in the first series of experiments .
in each case , a well - defined plexus of varicose fibers and terminals was identified in the cg .
nucleus of the solitary tract .
the medial subnucleus of the nts was injected at different rostro - caudal levels in five experiments .

the pattern of axonal labeling in the cg was similar in each of these , and is represented by experiment nts 7 in which the injection site was centered in the medial subnucleus at the level of the area postrema ( shaded area in fig . 6a ) .

caudally , anterogradely labeled efferent fibers entered the cg mainly from the parabrachial complex, coursing medially across the fascicles of the trochlear nerve and the mesencephalic trigeminal tract , to form a dense plexus of varicose fibers in - the ventral aspect of the cglv and adjacent cgm ( fig . 6e ) .

further rostrally , at the intercollicular level , terminal fibers were predominantly located in the medioventral part of the cglv and cgm , and extending into the lateral portion of the dorsal raphe nucleus ( fig . 6d ) .
individual varicose fibers also ran dorsally into the cgd ( fig . 6d , e ) .
in the anterior portion of the cg the density of labeled fibers was sparser , but the majority of efferent axons was still found in the ventral cgm and the medioventral cglv ( fig . 6b , c ) .
the posterior portion of the midline dorsal raphe was largely devoid of fibers from the medial nts , but the anterior portion was moderately densely innervated ( fig . 6c ) .
the projection from the medial nts to the cg was bilateral with an ipsilateral predominance , in agreement with the retrograde transport experiments .
dorsomedial medulla .
in four rats the pha - l injections were placed into the dmm .
in experiment dmm 2 , the center of the injection was located just ventral to the nucleus prepositus and lateral to the medial longitudinal fasciculus ( dots in fig . 7a ) .
pha - l labeled fibers were widespread in the lateroventral subdivision of the cg .
caudally , they were located predominantly in the ventral part of the cglv , in the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus and in the midline dorsal raphe nucleus ( fig . 7e ) .

at the midlevel of the cg , varicose fibers were present in fairly high density in the midline and lateral dorsal raphe nucleus ( fig . 7c , d ) , whereas in the cglv the labeled fibers were more sparsely and diffusely distributed .
rostrally in the cct , labeled fibers tended to accumulate bilaterally in the lateral aspect of the cglv , in the region of the mesencephalic trigeminal neurons ( fig . 7b , c ) .
dense innervation was also seen in the supraoculomotor nucleus ( fig . 7b ) .
only sparse innervation was present in the cgd and the cgld ( fig . 7b - d ) .
The innervation from the DMM to the CG was bilaterally symmetric, in agreement with the retrograde transport experiments (above).
ventrolateral medulla .
five rats received injections of pha - l into the ventrolateral medulla at different rostrocaudal levels .

the results were similar in all of these experiments , and are represented by experiment vlm 3, in which the pha - l deposit was located just ventral to the nucleus ambiguus ( dots in fig . 8a ) at the level of transition from the c1 adrenergic to the a1 noradrenergic group .

efferent fibers entered the cg caudally through the parabrachial complex , across the fascicles of the trochlear nucleus and the mesencephalic trigeminal tract , to innervate diffusely the posterior part of the cg ( fig . 8e ) .
in the anterior portion of the cg , prominent fiber labeling was present dorsally in the cglv and the cgd ( fig . 8b - d ) .
in the latter , the fibers predominantly innervated the cluster of large neurons located in the center of the cgd( indicated by dashed lines in fig . 8b , c cf .
Fig. lA',B').
the cgld contained only a few individual labeled fibers .
the projection from the vlm to the cg was bilateral with an equal density of efferent fibers on either side , in agreement with the retrograde transport studies ( above ) .

in summary , pha - l injections into the medullary adrenergic and noradrenergic cell groups resulted in three distinct patterns of anterogradely labeled axons ( figs . 6 - 8 ) in the cg subdivisions that also exhibited thir , dbhir , or pnmtir fibers ( compare with fig . 2 see also fig . 9 ) .
Combined anterograde tracing and immunohistochemistry
to determine which anterogradely labeled fibers in the cg were catecholaminergic , we employed a double immunofluorescence technique using antisera against pha - l and either dbh or pnmt .

midbrain sections from cases with pha - l injections into the a2 / c2 cell group in the medial nts ( n = 21 , into the al / cl cell group in the vlm ( n = l ) , or into the c3 cell group in the dmm ( n = 1 ) were processed using each antiserum .
adjacent series from these cases which were processed for pha - l immunoperoxidase histochemistry showed the expected patterns of anterograde fiber labeling , as described above .

high magnification fluorescence microscopy revealed substantial numbers of varicose fibers and terminals that were both pha - land dbhir ( figs . 10 , 11a , a ) or pha - land pnmtir ( fig . 1 lb , b ) , although the numbers of double - labeled fibers were small compared to the profusion of single - labeled fibers with each antiserum .
double - labeled structures were most frequently found in the dorsal raphe nucleus ( e . g . , fig .
loa , a ) and the medial portion of the cglv , but were present in smaller numbers throughout the dbhand pnmtir terminal fields in the cg .
in agreement with the retrograde transport data , double - labeled fibers were predominantly found on the ipsilateral side of the brain .
the double - labeled varicosities and intensely beaded fibers presumably indicated the presence of synaptic contacts that use noradrenaline or adrenaline as neurotransmitters .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
Our results indicate that noradrenergic neurons in the A1 and A2 groups and adrenergic neurons in the C1 and C3 groups are major sources of medullary afferents to the CG.

In particular, A2 neurons in the NTS contribute to a dense noradrenergic fiber plexus in the caudal ventral part of the CGlv, adjacent to the lateral aspects of the dorsal raphe and laterodorsal tegmental nuclei.
Adrenergic C3 neurons in the DMM contribute to an adrenergic terminal field in the ventral CGlv.
In contrast, adrenergic C1 and noradrenergic A1 neurons in the ventrolateral medulla more heavily innervate the dorsal part of the CGlv, bordering the CGld.
Technical considerations

Although there are extensive noradrenergic and adrenergic terminal fields in the CG of medullary origin, a majority of medullary neurons that were retrogradely labeled from the CG did not stain for catecholamine synthetic enzymes.
Our injections were clearly confined to the CG; hence, it is unlikely that we included cells that do not project to the CG in our analysis.

Furthermore, the numbers of immunoreactive cells seen per section were similar to those reported in previous studies using different antisera (e.g., Ruggiero et al., 85; Tucker and Saper, 871, so that our immunocytochemistry appears to be sufficiently sensitive.
We conclude, therefore, that many non-catecholaminergic neurons in the DMM, NTS, and VLM contribute axons to terminal fields in the CG where they are intermixed with catecholaminergic fibers.

In agreement with this interpretation, our anterograde transport studies identified many PHA-L-labeled axons, and many catecholaminergic axons, but double-labeled fibers were more sparse and difficult to find in the CG.
We attribute this problem to several technical limitations of the technique that we used.
First, the PHA-L method by nature labels the efferents from only a small population of neurons.
Hence, many catecholaminergic neurons in the cell group containing the injection site (and their axons in the CG) may not be labeled by the anterograde tracer.
Second, the fluorescent PHA-L method that we used may be slightly less sensitive than the immunoperoxidase method.
Although we did not quantify the numbers of labeled fibers, it appeared that the fiber densities were marginally greater in the immunoperoxidase series from the same brains.
It is possible that the smaller, less intensely labeled axom that are most difficult to stain may be disproportionately catecholaminergic.
Finally, the visual complexity of the innervation patterns with each marker makes the identification of labeled fibers difficult (see, e.g., Figs. 10, 11).
We have partially compensated for this problem by using photographic overlays, thus allowing us to identify even short pieces of axons that are double-labeled in a haystack of single-labeled fibers.

However, in areas of dense innervation the random apparent overlap of labeled structures (particularly terminals) that in fact are located in slightly different planes makes this procedure difficult to apply.
Hence, we have not been able to analyze as thoroughly the densest areas of the plexus, where the bulk of doublelabeled structures may be located.
Nevertheless, our observations indicate that catecholaminergic axons contribute to all of the CGlv terminal fields labeled with PHA-L from the DMM, NTS, and VLM.

Although it is difficult to exclude the possibility that there may be a differential contribution by catecholaminergic axons to some portion of these fields, it is likely that the medullary innervation of the CG arises from mixed catecholaminergic and non-catecholaminergic axons throughout.
Medullary catecholaminergic afferents to the CG

Previous studies examining medullary afferents to the CG in the rat (Beitz, '82; Morrell and Pfaff, '83; Hamba et al., '90) are difficult to compare with our own results, as the injections of retrograde tracers vary with respect to rostrocaudal and dorso-ventral level of placement.
We deliberately placed our injections into the region of densest catecholaminergic innervation, in the ventrolateral division of the CG at the intercollicular level.
These experiments resulted in substantial numbers of retrogradely labeled neurons in medullary cell groups that contain catecholaminergic neurons, including the NTS, the DMM, and the VLM.
Morrell and Pfaff ('83) and Hamba et al. ('90) reported retrograde labeling of numerous neurons in the VLM and DMM, but few in the NTS.

However, their injection sites were placed more dorsally in the CGlv, causing retrograde labeling of neurons in the ventromedial part of the caudal spinal trigeminal nucleus that was not present in our experiments.
Beitz ('82) found retrograde labeling of neurons in the NTS and the VLM mainly after injections placed into the lateroventral component of the CG, a finding that is consistent with our own results.
Kwiat and Basbaum ('90) recently examined the overall origin of catecholaminergic afferents to the CG.

They confirmed our preliminary report (Herbert and Saper, '88) that tyrosine hydroxylase-immunoreactive neurons in the NTS, the DMM, and the VLM project to the CG, also identifying noradrenergic neurons in the locus coeruleus and the A5 and A7 groups as contributing to this innervation.

Previous studies employing lesions of the locus coeruleus had come to conflicting conclusions concerning its contribution to catecholaminergic innervation of the CG (Loizou, '69; Levitt and Moore, '79).

Our results indicate that noradrenergic fibers to the PAG from the medulla enter through the lateral edge of the CG, near the locus coeruleus, so that locus coeruleus lesions may have disrupted, in part, the medullary afferents as well.

Recently Fritschy and Grzanna ('90) employed anterograde transport of PHA-L combined with immunocytochemistry for dopamine P-hydroxylase to identify noradrenergic innervation arising from the locus coeruleus (Fritschy and Grzanna, '90).
They reported only limited innervation of the CG, which largely overlaps with the noradrenergic terminal fields that we found arising from the medulla.
However, it would be interesting to compare directly the relative innervation patterns within the CG of the pontine and medullary noradrenergic afFerents.
We did not address the extent to which the projections from the medullary catecholaminergic cell groups to the CG represent collaterals of other medullary catecholaminergic projections.

The same cell groups that we found innervating the CG also project in the forebrain to the hypothalamus (median preoptic, paraventricular and supraoptic nuclei) and in the brainstem to the parabrachial nucleus (Sawchenko and Swanson, '81, '82; Blessing et al., '82; Saper et al., '83; Milner et al., '86; Tucker et al., '87; Cunningham and Sawchenko, '88; Cunningham et al., '90).
In addition the C1 and C3 adrenergic groups innervate the locus coeruleus, and many rostral C1 neurons innervate the spinal cord (Ross et al., '84; Pieribone et al., '88; Minson et al., '90).

Double retrograde labeling combined with immunocytochemistry to tyrosine hydroxylase indicates that many of the catecholaminergic neurons in the medulla that project to the CG also send axon collaterals to the spinal cord (Kwiat and Basbaum, '90).

These results are consistent with earlier studies showing that a large proportion of baroreceptive Cl cells that send axons to the spinal cord also have ascending collaterals (Haselton and Guyenet, 'go), but very few of these apparently reach the hypothalamus (Tucker et al., '87).
These observations suggest that the CG may be a major terminal field for adrenergic s o n s from sympathoexcitatory neurons.
Topographic organization of the CG and its connections
The anatomical parcellation of the CG used in this study was derived from the cytoarchitectonic studies of Beitz ('82, '85; Beitz and Shepard, '85) and Paxinos and Watson ('86).
Our results in general support their observations dividing the CG into dorsal, laterodorsal, lateroventral, and medial components.
Staining for NADPH-diaphorase demonstrated the sharp distinction between the CGld and the adjacent CGd and CGlv.

These borders were also respected by the medullary afferents that we traced: axons from the DMM and NTS were clearly concentrated in the ventral part of the CGlv whereas the VLM afferents were densest in the dorsal part of the CGlv and in the CGd.
None of the medullary fields we injected projected to the CGld, nor did this latter subdivision receive much catecholaminergic innervation.
The CGd, on the other hand, received an extensive projection from the VLM, but none of it was catecholaminergic.
We also identified a rostro-caudal gradient within the medullary afferents to the CG.
The NTS projection to the ventral part of the CGlv was most dense caudally, as was the VLM projection to the dorsal CGlv.
The DMM projection was more evenly distributed in a rostro-caudal dimension.
These observations are consistent with the findings of Beitz ('821, who noted that larger numbers of NTS and VLM cells were retrogradely labeled from caudal as opposed to rostral CGlv sites.
Other afferents to the CG follow this same pattern of topographical organization.

The NTS terminal zone in the caudal ventral CGlv overlaps with afferents from the infralimbic cortex (Hurley et al., '91; Shipley et al., '911, the central nucleus of the amygdala (Gray and Magnuson, '87; Rizvi et al., '911, the substantia innominata (Grove, '88); the median preoptic nucleus (Swanson et al., '87; Simerly and Swanson, '881, the lateral hypothalamus (Saper et al., '79; Luiten et al., '87; Allen and Cechetto, '90; Veening et al., '901, and the lateral parabrachial nucleus (Saper and Loewy, '80; Beitz, '82).
As catecholaminergic neurons in the NTS receive direct vagal afferents (Sumal et al., '83), it is likely that the caudal ventral CGlv is concerned with autonomic control.

The caudodorsal CGlv, which is the terminal field for VLM afferents, also receives inputs from forebrain structures including the prelimbic cortex (Hurley et al., '911, the central nucleus of the amygdala (Gray and Magnuson, '87; Rivzi et al., '911, the dorsomedial nucleus of the hypothalamus (Luiten et al., '87; ter Horst and Luiten, '861, the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus (Saper et al., '76; Luiten et al., '87; Dornan et al., 'go), the dorsal premammillary nucleus, and the zona incerta (Luiten et al., '87).

In addition, it receives somatosensory (presumably nociceptive) information from lamina I of the spinal cord (Mehler et al., '60; Swett et al., '85; Yezierski, '88) and the spinal trigeminal nucleus (Hamba et al., 'go), suggesting a role in somatosensory processing.

Efferents from the CGlv reach the same hypothalamic and basal forebrain sites that project to it (Tohyama et al., '78; Berk and Finkelstein, '82; Eberhart et al., '85; Hamba et al., '90); the intralaminar, paraventricular, and reticular nuclei of the thalamus (Eberhart et al., '85; Carstens et al., '90; Tohyama et al., '78); the parabrachial nucleus (Moga et al., '90) and nucleus of the solitary tract (Bandler and Tork, '87; Herbert and Saper, unpublished data); and the medullary raphe (Abols and Basbaum, '81; Beitz et al., '83) and reticular formation (Sakuma and Pfaff, '80; van Bockstaele et al., '89).
Little is known, however, about the topographic arrangement of these projection neurons with respect to afferents to the CGlv.
Functional organization of the CG
The topographic relationships of the CG have been associated with a variety of physiological responses.
Nociceptiue afferents from the spinal cord and spinal trigeminal nucleus terminate primarily in the dorsal part of the CGlv (Mehler et al., '60; Yezierski, '88; Hambaet al., '90).

On the other hand, analgesic responses can be recorded during stimulation of the ventral CGlv as well as the areas dorsal to it (Ness and Gebhart, '871, and the descending projection to the nucleus raphe magnus, which has been associated with this response, originates from the ventral CGlv (Abols and Basbaum, '81; Beitz et al., '83).
Hence it is likely that intrinsic connections between the different subdivisions of the CG may be involved in mediating the modulation of nociception.
It would be interesting to determine whether specific sets of catecholaminergic terminals in the CG play a role in this process.
The CG has also been implicated in a variety of behavioral processes, including sexual receptivity in female rats (Sakuma and Pfaff, '80).
The lordotic posture, which facilitates mounting by male rats, is disrupted by lesions of the CG in estrogen-primed females.
The lordosis response is facilitated by estrogen-sensitive neurons in the ventrolatera1 part of the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus (see Sakuma and Pfaff, '79).

A projection to the CG from the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus, in part originating from enkephalin and substance P immunoreactive neurons, has been identified (Saper et al., '76; Krieger et al., '79; Akaishi and Sakuma, '86; Yamano et al., '86; Chung et al., '90; Dornan et al., '90).
Most of these axons end in the dorsal and medial parts of the CGlv.

On the other hand, descending projections to parts of the gigantocellular and magnocellular medullary reticular formation that are important in motor response primarily originate from neurons in the more ventral CGlv (Sakuma and Pfaff, '80).

Furthermore, injections of excitatory amino acids, or antagonists of GABA, into the CG, particularly the CGlv, produce behavioral hyperresponsiveness to innocuous cutaneous stimuli on the contralateral body surface (Bandler et al., '85a,b).
Thus, the descending sensory and motor connections of the CGlv may allow it to modulate a variety of behavioral responses.
The interactions of catecholaminergic inputs with other afferents to the CGlv may allow them to influence behavioral responses regulated by the CG.

A marked increase in blood pressure and heart rate is often associated with behavioral responses elicited by injections of excitatory agents into the CGlv of the cat (McDougall et al., '85; Carrive et al., '88, '89).

Although these response patterns are similar to the "defense reaction" elicited by electrical stimulation of parts of the hypothalamus and amygdala, more careful dissection of the functional anatomy of the CG has demonstrated that the CG responses are more complex.

Stimulation sites in the dorsal part of the rostral CGlv in the cat demonstrate increases in arterial pressure and iliac and renal artery resistance, accompanied by behavior characterized as "threat display" (Carrive et al., '89).
The most responsive site for this pattern corresponds well with the terminal field for catecholaminergic axons from the VLM in the rat.

Injection of retrograde tracers into the caudal part of the subretrofacial region in the cat (the rostral VLM at approximately the same level as our PHA-L injections) labeled neurons in the rostral CGlv (Carrive et al., '88, '891, and injections of anterograde tracer into this part of the CGlv labeled axons innervating the subretrofacial region (Carrive et al., '88).
Injection of retrograde tracer into the rostral pole of the subretrofacial nucleus in the cat labeled neurons in the CGd and the caudal ventral part of the CGlv (Carrive et al., '89).

We found anterogradely labeled axons from the VLM in the CGd of the rat, but none of these were catecholaminergic, and no cardiovascular responses are elicited in this area in the cat (Bandler et al., '85a,b; Carrive et al., '88, '89).
The caudal ventral CGlv is preferentially innervated by the NTS, including theA2 cell group in the rat.

Electrical or chemical stimulation in this area in the cat produces a distinct pattern of increased arterial pressure and'renal artery resistance, with a fall in iliac artery resistance (i.e., increased hindlimb blood flow) and an escape behavior pattern (Carrive et al., '89).

Stimulation of an intermediate portion of the CGlv was noted in preliminary experiments in the cat to cause a fall in blood pressure and arterial resistance in both the renal and iliac beds (Carrive et al., '89), suggesting that the functional organization of cardiovascular regulatory responses in the CG may be quite complex.
Similar effects produced by chemical stimulation in the rat have been less extensively studied (e.g., Robinson, '87).

However, the marked innervation by catecholaminergic afferents from the medulla of each of the CG sites involved in cardiovascular control suggests that these inputs may play an important role in cardiovascular regulation.
